abstracts.cdata!:
This Performance Assessment Report
            concurs largely with the Implementation Completion Report,
            and Evaluation Summary's ratings of satisfactory
            project outcome, high institutional development impact, as
            well as highly satisfactory Bank performance, and
            satisfactory Borrower performance, though downgrades its
            sustainability to likely from a highly likely rating.
            Lessons drawn from the project experience, suggest that the
            design of railway concessions should aim to avoid
            establishing government-owned patrimony/landlord
            corporations, since such corporations tend to interfere with
            the management of the concession, with no clear gains for
            the government. Therefore, selling rather than leasing the
            equipment to the concessionaire, leads to a cleaner
            concession arrangement, and thus precludes the need for a
            patrimony corporation. The Bank's experience with
            railway concessions contributes to designing, and financing
            of such operations, in particular, in attracting private
            investors to difficult infrastructure sectors. However, it
            is also suggested that renegotiation of infrastructure
            concessions should be avoided, or deferred as possible,
            since it undermines credibility of the concession system
            itself. And, the delicate issue of staff redundancy, should
            be managed with adequate compensation, providing pensions
            under exceptional early retirements, and outsourcing-company
            work to displaced staff.

abstracts.cdata!:
The achievement of the project objective
            is rated highly satisfactory, with project sustainability
            highly likely. Overall, World Bank performance is rated
            highly satisfactory. Given the large effort during the fast
            track preparation, the deep involvement of the implementing
            agency, and especially the privatization committee, overall
            Borrower performance is rated satisfactory. Lessons learned
            included the following: Continuity in staffing of
            supervision missions by the Bank is important. The original
            task manager maintained her participation in the project
            from 1995 until 1998, the railway specialist and the
            operations officer from 1995 to 2001. This greatly
            contributed to the project's success. The project
            involved a large donor coordination effort, much of which
            was successful. A landlord company is not an adequate
            arrangement in railway concessions. Other mechanisms to
            monitor the concession can be implemented which are less
            costly and at lest as efficient. The rolling concession
            arrangement--an innovative feature of this
            concession--provides the incentive framework for private
            participation in railway operations. Timely donor
            contribution to finance large and costly infrastructure is
            essential to support the launching of a concession such as
            for railway services, which is profitable for the entire
            economy but which does not have a very high financial viability.

18155191.theme: Regional integration,State-owned enterprise restructuring and privatization,Regulation and competition policy
18155191.majtheme: Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of Emergency Railway
            Rehabilitation Project are to contribute to the
            revitalization of a major transport service promoting
            competitiveness and regional integration, by providing the
            financing necessary to carry out the long overdue
            rehabilitation of the publicly-owned railway infrastructure
            and equipment assets. The main components of the project are
            as follows: 1) infrastructure rehabilitation which covers
            selective track renewal and repair, ballasting, bridge and
            culvert repairs, embankment repairs, installation of
            weighing equipment, and some building repairs; 2) equipment
            rehabilitation and acquisition including the motive power
            and rolling stock rehabilitation component, the maintenance
            equipment component, the telecommunication component, and
            the component related to the acquisition of computers; and
            3) works supervision and training.
